Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2008 03:31PM DiamondJAL wrote: I did at one point look into that, I believe it was that same program but they wanted to send me to the doctors of their choice and to me, that was unacceptable......but then again, that was when I had insurance and didn't really need the program.  Luckily, all got all my scans in for this year before I lost all coverage so unless something unforeseen happens, I am o.k. for another year and hopefully by this time next year, will have a job with coverage.  I just need normal coverage for everyday things but they don't cover that.  But the lapse in coverage also scares me, if I don't get coverage within 63 days, it could mean more problems.  I guess while I am currently unemployed, I am going to be making a ton more phone calls and rattling some cages to get some answers. It is a scary thing to always wonder, what if they missed something.  What if in between annual scans, something develops.  What if they don't order the right test this year.  So much to worry about and anyone that hasn't faced it, doesn't understand.......especially the insurance industry.
Posts.Title: Dense Breasts Ask for MRI Aug242007 Beesie

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2008 08:01AM DiamondJAL wrote: Hi all, haven't been on the site for awhile, I am a 4 year survivor at the age of 46.  I agree that an MRI is a life saving tool.  As my Onc explained to me, none of the tests themselves are perfect but they all compliment each other.  The MRI flags everything, good or bad, it's up to the doctors and or other tests/biopsies to determine what it is. I found my lump close to the skin and I also have very lumpy, dense breasts.  My lump was seen on the mammo and on the ultrasound but luckily, my surgeon ordered the MRI 1 week before surgery.  The MRI spotted a 2nd smaller tumor hiding behind the small 2 cm tumor that we already knew was there.  He said based on where it was, most likely he would have removed it with the 1st one anyhow but this way, he knew it was there.  My opinion.....the problem is not with the doctors or the hospitals, it it with the insurance industry that is allowed to dictate what they feel is medically necessary to save my life.  When these peoples mother, wife, daughter is diagnosed with breast cancer some day, I want them to accept the decision from an insurance company that Noooooooo, we don't think you need that test to save her life, we are not paying for it.  I guess I was lucky in that the insurance that I had at the time said that if my doctors ordered the MRI as a diagnostic, then it was covered, period.  I also have titanium markers in my breasts so that they don't end up doing biopsies on things they have already tested.  My cysts are so hard that it took 2 men to push the biopsy needle thru my breast and into the cysts for testing. Just remember ladies, it is your life and your health and you have the right to request anything and any 2nd opinion that you need.  If someone laughs at you, then you don't want that person for your doctor.   I can't even get insurance right now, I lost my job in July after 19 years with a major airline and now have nothing and I cannot afford to pay for it.  I am praying that our new president puts this as a priority on his agenda for the women in the USA.  I was told I make too much on unemployment to qualify for any assistance and there are no exceptions for cancer patients, doesn't matter that I can't even pay all of my bills.  If anyone out there knows of any programs that I haven't found in my research yet, please contact me. Thanks......Judy
Posts.Title: Dense Breasts Ask for MRI Aug242007 Beesie

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2008 01:09PM DiamondJAL wrote: PA Lady.....just wondering what part of PA you are from?  I'm in PA also, near Pittsburgh.   Four year survivor ladies and yes, it does come back.  Mine came back thick, dark and curly but has since straightened out with a slight wave if I let it go natural....I like to straighten it.  I'd say it was 8 to 10 weeks when it started growing and then it goes nuts.  I know I was having my radiation about a month after my last chemo and it was there but I was still wearing my wig.  Wore the wig to work to feel normal but at home, it was natural or bandanas.  I'll never forget the day I went to pen the door when someone was knocking and I forgot I didn't have anything on but my bald head.......my poor brother was standing there and had never seen me bald.....I think his eyeballs popped out.  My eyebrows and lashes thinned but didn't lose all of them.  I am a hairy person by nature and I don't mind telling you that there are times that I wish my body was back to the days when I didn't have some of the hair......like my fuzzy facial hair.  I had an absolutely flawless complexion when my hair was back in short and the facial hair hadn't really come back yet.  Now don't think I have a beard ladies.....just that light fuzzy face hair that no woman wants.  haha I spent my 1 year cancer free in Aruba for Thanksgiving and it was incredible.....totally wig free and it was wonderful.  By the way, I did use the Nioxin also when my hair was coming back in and I know it helped it to come back in more even and healthy.  p.s.......how do you insert pics?  I don't seem to be able to get it to work. Judy
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2008 02:35PM - edited Nov 22, 2008 02:50PM by DiamondJAL ShellyJo.....I love that word, CANCERVERSARY.......I say we make it an official cancer survivors word!  Should be take a poll?  lol     Boston huh?  I bet you are cold.  I am in PA and it has been freezing this week, hasn't gone about 30, last night was in the single digits with wind chill.  Bbbbrrrrr, only thing it's good for is hot flashes.  I'll try the drag and drop, see if it works.  I created a panoramic pic of some before, during and after pics.....want to see if I can transfer it.  Last pic on the view is me and my mom......we are both survivors.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2008 11:31PM DiamondJAL wrote: Yep, know them all.....squirrel hill, shadyside, that's all right in the heart of Pittsburgh.  Matter of fact, Shadyside is connected to where my Oncologist is at Hillman Cancer Center.  Had to laugh, yes you are right, after everything we endure, we are permitted to complain about anything we want.  lol I feel great when I exercise, just don't have the motivation to get moving lately.  I prefer to be outside working but now it's too cold.  When it's nice, I'm outside cutting grass, weed wacking, cutting down trees, whatever needs done.......feel great when i put in a days work like that.  Well, I gotta get to bed, my 16 year old son has a fashion show tomorrow.  Junior class fundraiser for the prom.  Oh how fast they grow up.  He was just a baby, now he's 6' tall.....ugggggggggg.  I lost touch on this site for awhile since I've been clean but it's nice to be back and talking to people again.  Stay in touch and good luck......my prayers are with you.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2008 10:55PM DiamondJAL wrote: Hey sandy.......cool, right in Pittsburgh or suburbs?  I live near the airport in the country.  Figure a little bit of facial hair, even if it is fuzzy is a small price to pay for being alive.  They have things to remove hair.  Damn, we cry cause we lose it and we cry cause it comes back, huh/  lolol Don't have near the oil that I used to, menopause is taking care of that now.  I used to be able to fry an egg on my face.  I'm sitting here looking at my treadmill collect dust and playing on the computer.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2008 05:52PM DiamondJAL wrote: What great news Lisa......congrats but please be sure to follow up as recommended, don't let anything go.  The sooner you follow up, the sooner you'll have all your answers.  Too many women wait for alot of things and that is half the battle.
Posts.Title: biopsy results thebabylisa shap

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2008 09:15PM DiamondJAL wrote: Please don't think I'm being rude but why are women going to general surgeons for breast biopsies?  It was explained to me that you wouldn't take your car for transmission work to an oil change place so why would you take your breasts anywhere than where they specialize on breasts?  I'm sure there are many qualified GS's but they are not breast specialists.  When my mom had it 15 years ago, her OB was 'sure' her lump was nothing and took it out in his office.  My mom trusted him.....little did she know the biopsy would come back positive.  When she finally got to the breast surgeon, he was furious that a doctor would do that to her.  It was not her fault, she trusted her doctor but the doctor should have known to send her to a specialist and / or oncologist right away.  Again, I'm not trying to be mean ladies, I would never do that....I know what an ordeal you are going through but please maybe look for other options in your area. Also, I don't understand this wire thing and having to be cut that way.  I had biopsies by core needle samples and stereotactic, which is the one they use to extract the calcifications.  Is this not standard procedure or is it up to the surgeon how to remove the calcifications?  Or does it depend on the calcification?  I pray that all of you are o.k.
Posts.Title: ALSO Waiting for Test Results Dorothy_2008 Dorothy_2008

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2008 05:58PM DiamondJAL wrote: You'll get it back, don't worry.  Everyone is different, do what's comfortable and listen to your doctors.  I was outside weed wacking 6 months after surgery.  It's just like getting back into shape.  Sore as hell to start out but then you start getting back into condition.  I had lumpectomy and lost 3 nodes.....I think the nodes hurt worse than the rest, the numbness drove me nuts.  Plus, I worked a desk job so having my hand up on the mouse for the computer all day hurt.  Now it feels fine.....still tiny bit numb on the actual incision site but other than that, feel great.  I had alot of stabbing pain when I was healing in my armpit and my Onc explained that as your nerves are trying to come back to gether and heal, it's like little shock waves being sent out.  I thought someone had a voodoo doll and was stabbing me in the armpit.  haha
Posts.Title: range of motion after surgery rayhope karen1956

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2008 07:14PM DiamondJAL wrote: Hi ladies, I'm Judy and I just have to chime in here......I'm reading all your posts and cracking up.....you all sound way too much like me.  lol     My3girls, did I read that you worked for the airlines?  What part of ohio are you in?    I had just started my 19th year at US Airways in June and they canned my job in July at Pittsburgh airport.  I've always had a job for 30 years, not sure how to handle this.  There's not much out there and what is there, they want to pay peanuts.  Damn, it's hard to start over at 46, all my seniority, time off, etc., this really is hard.  I too had a louse for a husband, cheated on me with the bottle then moved on to sleezy women that he picked up in the bars.   I could handle what he did to me but not what he did to his son's life.  I have an awesome 16 year old son.  I wanna go on the cruise too please.   For my one year cancer free anniversary (2005), I spent Thanksgiving in Aruba......oh it was incredible.  Now I'm spending it in snow...BBbbrrrrr. And I loved that word "ASSitude.....here's another one someone said to me when I said I was 4 years cancer free, she said Happy CANCERversary!
